) This Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) section provides guidance on the Pass-Through Control System (PCS) database. and (
) Purpose: This IRM is to describe the establishment and maintenance of PCS database. (
) Audience: Field Examination Revenue Agents (RAs) and campus RAs, Compliance Offers (TCOs), Tax Examiners (TEs) and Clerks working through entities and/or their investors linked on PCS. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE), ters, Examination Field and Campus Policy (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP) (
) Program Owner: Program Manager, Campus Examination and Field (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP:CEFS) (
) Primary Stakeholders: SB/SE, Large Business and Industry (LB&I), and Appeals (

) Program Goals: PCS is a database used to create an electronic linkage between pass-through entities and their underlying partners. Linking in instances is mandatory. Linkage allows for the proper control of statutes ensures all relevant partners are processed. (
) Contact Information: To recommend changes or make any other related to this IRM section, see IRM
, Providing Feedback About IRM Section - Outside of Clearance. (

) PCS was created to monitor and control pass-through entity investors. through entities can have many partners and many levels of tiering. occurs when an investor in a pass-through entity is also a pass-through This complexity can make it difficult to keep track of statutes and monitor the investors. (

) PCS control is a policy that was established in response to the provisions of the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act (TEFRA) of has been expanded to cover other pass-through entities that fall outside TEFRA. (

Monitoring and evaluating area office and campus examination PCS quality control procedures. (

4.29 Pass-Through Control System
Field Territory Managers, Field Area Directors, Director over LB&I Ogden and Director, Examination - Brookhaven, are responsible for ensuring that:

An accurate database is established by designating PCS responsibilities and activities; and A PCS quality control system is implemented. This includes timely action on PCS record establishments, PCS reports, and Audit Information Man- agement System (AIMS) TC
Reject Registers. It also includes timely processing of TEFRA notices and Appeals settlement letters (campus only).
Area office Examination Managers and campus Field Support managers are responsible for: a. Maintaining an updated copy of IRM

, Pass-Through Control (PCS) Handbook, in their respective functions; b. Ensuring the training of technical and clerical employees in PCS dures; and c. Establishing PCS records and acting on PCS reports in a timely to assure an accurate PCS database. The campus PCS Coordinator works with: • The other PCS coordinator(s) • Technical Services TEFRA Coordinators • Their local employees • Other campus functional areas to ensure timely processing of related activities The campus PCS Coordinator is charged with: • Identifying and resolving technical problems • Identifying and coordinating the resolution of PCS systemic Following are speciﬁc campus PCS Coordinator responsibilities: a. Coordinate PCS operations among areas, Campus Pass-through Functions (CPFs), and other campus functions; b. Ensure timely processing and distribution of PCS output; c. Ensure that all requests for establishment and linkage on PCS are reviewed for accuracy, completeness, and timeliness; d. Maintain accuracy of the PCS database by ensuring that action reports are worked in required time frames; e. Resolve AIMS problems; f. 4.29 Pass-Through Control System
) The PCS provides the necessary information to establish an AIMS record. on (

) The PCS is a separate database that interacts with AIMS. Establishing the AIMS record indirectly through the PCS instead of directly through AIMS not change the normal AIMS processing. a. If the PCS provides incomplete or inaccurate information, the AIMS record will not establish, and the information will reject. b. If the requested record already exists on AIMS, the PCS request will alter any information on the existing AIMS record except for updating Partnership Investor Control File (PICF) Code. (

) A PCS record may only be established by inputting information from PCS forms. Once the record is established on the PCS, the record will remain the PCS for six months even if the record does not establish on AIMS. priate AIMS procedures must be taken for all PCS records that do not establish on AIMS. (

) Investor records are established on the PCS by the use of CC TSLOD. The PCS will access the local Taxpayer Information File (TIF) to determine if an account exists on Master File (MF) for an investor. The PCS also veriﬁes name control. If the TIF information does not match MF, AIMS creates a Reject Record. (

) The PCS receives certain database elements from AIMS and carries database elements that are unique and exclusive to the PCS. a. Unique and exclusive elements to the PCS are updated by using PCS forms and command codes. b. Elements that are common to AIMS and the PCS are updated by AIMS forms and command codes. Note: The one exception to this rule is CC MSCHG (Form
, PCS Mass Change, IRM
, Mass Change, (MSCHG)) which also updates certain ﬁelds on AIMS. Updates to AIMS and the PCS using this code are made during nightly processing at the Memphis Computer (MCC). (

, and the Upper Section of the Electronic Linkage Forms. When a subsidiary return is identiﬁed, both the parent and the subsidiary to be linked. First, a CC TSLODP will be input to link the parent to the key case. The existence of a normal tier value ( # or blank) on the key case will result in establishment of the parent as an investor, but a “P” will be displayed on tier indicator of the partner record. A CC TSLODP will not generate an to the parent. The NBAP to the subsidiary returns is all that is needed. A CC TSLODS will then be used to load the subsidiary return(s). The Non- Master File (NMF) AIMS record must be created, and then the CC TSLODS will be input. The CC TSLODS will establish the NMF linkage, and an “S” be displayed on the tier indicator of the partner record. Special User Message should be used to cross reference the parent and sidiary returns. Use TSCHG item
to add Special User Message. For on parents add “Sub: EIN(s)” and on subsidiary returns add “Par: EIN(s)”. Where Employee Identiﬁcation Number (EIN) is the actual EIN of the entity.
4.29.2.3.3 (11-27-2017) Establishing TEFRA Parent/Subsidiary Returns

First, a CC TSLODP will be input to link the parent to the key case. The existence of a normal tier value ( # or blank) on the key case will result in the establishment of the parent as an investor, but a “P” will be displayed on the tier indicator of the partner record. A CC TSLODP will not generate an NBAP to the parent. The NBAP to the subsidiary returns is all that is needed.

-Day Letters or FPAAs are generated, a CC TSNOT will be input as normal. PCS will identify the parent/sub relationship and generate two copies of the letters and two cover sheets. a. The notice address for both copies will use the subsidiary Schedule K-

information that was altered to reﬂect the parent information. b. Two cover sheet mailing addresses will also be generated. One cover sheet will have the parent address and the other will have the subsidiary address. The subsidiary cover sheet will have language to notify the sidiary that they are receiving a copy of the notice sent to the parent. (
) For corporate tax years beginning before June

, notices should be addressed to and agreements signed by the parent, as the subsidiaries have no legal authority to bind the parent to an agreement. If the agreement is for a partnership year(s) ending on or before the last day of a consolidated return year beginning on or after June
, then a currently authorized officer of the subsidiary corporation should sign the agreement and should do so in the name of the subsidiary corporation. See Treas. Reg.

)(iii). The signature and title of a current officer of the subsidiary corporation, who is au- thorized to bind the corporation, should be displayed in the signature block. The signature and title of a current officer of the common parent corporation, who is authorized bind the common parent corporation, should also be displayed in the signature block. (

) CC TSCLS is used to release the key case linkage freeze on AIMS investor records controlled on the PCS. Releasing the linkage freeze allows the investor return to process through full closure on AIMS. a. The input of CC TSCLS causes an interaction that reviews all the records of the investor and checks the Partnership Linkage Closed Indicator ﬁeld to insure that all partner linkages are closed. b. If an open linkage is found, an error message is displayed, and the closing process stops. c. The error message only displays the ﬁrst open linkage found. CC must be used to determine how many open linkages exist. (
) CC TSCLS does not remove key case linkages, it only releases the linkage freeze. To remove an erroneous linkage refer to the previous subsections.
